title.narrative: CO-Phasing out of coal fire plants

description.narrative: Vietnam is one of the world#s most vulnerable countries to climate change, and last year the Government of Vietnam (GoV) acknowledged this fact with its commendable Climate Vulnerable Forum (CVF) commitment to move to 100% renewable energy by 2050. This is complimented by other national energy strategies such as the 2012 Green Growth Strategy, the 2014 Green Growth Action Plan and the 2015 Renewable Energy Strategy, all in support of the Government meeting its commitments under the Paris Agreement through its Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC). Despite these commitments, however, Vietnam is arguably at the epicenter for future coal expansion as estimates from the current Power Master Plan VII project total capacity to increase more than 55,000 MW by 2030, accounting for 53 percent of the country#s total electricity production. When combined with the rest of South East Asia#s planned coal capacity increases, these investments would cripple collective efforts to keep global temperature rise below 2 degrees C. Despite these plans, analysis by the World Bank and others show that Vietnam has significant renewable energy potential to meet the needs of all its citizens. OVN seeks support from the European Climate Foundation of $USD 45,000 over what is anticipated to be the first year of a multi-year initiative, to amplify the work of the CCWG and help build capacity of NGOs in Vietnam to raise community voices and influence theGovernment#s shift away from coal and implementation of 100% renewable energy. The key activities of this project are to develop the advocacy materials, build capacity for CCWG core members for advocacy about energy sectors, create initial stages of platform or consultation between community and Gov on energy plan, including NDC and enhance cooperation/exchange within ASEAN region in mitigation and national influencing.

participating-org.narrative: In Vietnam , Oxfam is one of the leading international, non -governmental organisation. Since 1955, Oxfam is active in Vietnam withhumanitarian interventions and started development work in the late 1980's. Today, Oxfam works in 26 provinces with people, governments and civil society to promote equality and well-being through social and economic change.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
